column1: ā in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::father}}
ē in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::meh, longly held}}
ī in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::machine, longly held}}
ō in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::clover, longly held}}
ū in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::rude, longly held}}
ȳ in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::machine, longly held}}
a in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::Dinah}}
e in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::pet}}

i in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::pin}}, or {{c1::consonantal Y}} when {{c1::1) at the start of a word before another vowel, 2) within a word between two vowels, forming a diphthong with the former and also the consonant y before the following vowel.}}
o in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::orb, off}}
u in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::put}}
y in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::tu, über}}
ae is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::ai in aisle}}
au in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::ou in house}}
ei in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::reign}}
eu in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::pet plus put as one syllable (rare)}}
oe in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::oil}}
ui in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::gooey as one syllable}}, only in {{c1::huius, cuius, huic, cui, hui}}. Otherwise {{c1::not-diphthong}}
bs in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::ps}}
bt in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::pt}}
c is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::always hard: k}}
g is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::always hard: get not gem}}
h in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::soft aspirate}}
m in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::m}}, perhaps {{c1::with lips open and nasalized}} when {{c1::at the end of a word and following a vowel}}
q is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::always with u as in English, same sound as English, not French}}
r in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::trilled (Italian?)}}
s in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::see (voiceless), never ease (voiced)}}
t in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::tired, never nation nor mention}}
v in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::w}}
x in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::ks as in axle, never gz as in exert.}}
ch is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::always hard: blockhead, not church, from Greek chi}}
ph in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::uphill, not philosophy, from Greek phi}}
th in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::hothouse, not thin nor the, from Greek theta}}
rr in Latin is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::Watch the cur run.}}
tt is pronounced as in the English: {{c1::Admit ten.}}
long by position: short vowel followed by two or more consonants OR {{c1::x}}
long by position: short vowel followed by two or more consonants EXCEPT {{c1::qu, ch, ph, th, [:stop][:liquid]}}
the "stop" consonants are {{c1::p, b, t, d, c, and g}}
the "liquid" consonants are {{c1::r and l}}
